applicable_law: Hindu Succession Act, 1956 - Section 8 (Class I heirs)
court_jurisdiction: District Court having territorial jurisdiction over property

facts_pleadings.para1_introduction: That the plaintiffs are the legal heirs and Class I heirs of late Sh. [Father's Name] and late Smt. [Mother's Name], who died intestate on [Date] and [Date] respectively.
facts_pleadings.para2_heirship: That under Section 8 of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956, when a Hindu male dies intestate, his property devolves equally upon all Class I heirs. The plaintiffs (son/daughter) and [siblings] are all Class I heirs entitled to equal share.
facts_pleadings.para3_property: That the suit property described above was the self-acquired/ancestral property of late [Father's Name]. No will was ever executed by the deceased.
facts_pleadings.para4_fraud: That the defendant fraudulently obtained mutation of the entire property in her name by producing a forged will dated [Date] before the Municipal/Revenue authorities.
facts_pleadings.para5_forgery: That the said will is forged and fabricated. The signature does not match the deceased's genuine signature. The plaintiffs have filed FIR No. [X] under Sections 467, 420 IPC for forgery.
facts_pleadings.para6_no_consent: That the defendant obtained mutation without knowledge or consent of the plaintiffs, who are entitled legal heirs.
facts_pleadings.para7_suit_property: That the suit property is indivisible in nature and requires partition by metes and bounds through court-appointed commissioner.
facts_pleadings.para8_cause_of_action: That cause of action arose when plaintiffs discovered the fraudulent mutation on [Date]. The suit is within limitation under Article 65 of Limitation Act, 1963.
facts_pleadings.para9_jurisdiction: That this Hon'ble Court has jurisdiction as the suit property is situated within its territorial limits.
facts_pleadings.para10_valuation: That the suit is valued at Rs. [Amount] for court fee purposes and proper court fees have been paid.
facts_pleadings.para11_no_alternative: That no alternative remedy is available and civil suit is the only remedy.

prayers_reliefs: a) Declare that the will dated [Date] purportedly executed by late [Father's Name] is forged, fabricated, and void.
b) Declare that mutation entry No. [X] dated [Date] is illegal, invalid, and obtained by fraud.
c) Declare that plaintiffs are entitled to equal share (1/3rd each) in the suit property as Class I heirs under Hindu Succession Act, 1956.
d) Direct partition of the suit property by metes and bounds through court-appointed commissioner.
e) Grant permanent injunction restraining defendant from selling, mortgaging, or alienating the suit property.
f) Grant temporary injunction under Order 39 Rule 1 & 2 CPC pending final decision.
g) Award costs of the suit to plaintiffs.
h) Grant any other relief deemed fit by this Hon'ble Court.

interim_relief_application.prayer: Grant temporary injunction restraining defendant from alienating, selling, or creating third-party rights in suit property pending final decision
interim_relief_application.urgency: Property is in danger of being sold/mortgaged. Irreparable loss and injury to plaintiffs.
interim_relief_application.undertaking: Plaintiffs undertake to compensate defendant if injunction is wrongly granted.

format.verification: I, [Plaintiff 1 Name], do hereby verify that the contents of paras 1 to [X] are true to my personal knowledge and belief.

documents_to_attach: Annexure P-1: Death certificate of father
Annexure P-2: Death certificate of mother
Annexure P-3: Birth certificates / School certificates proving plaintiffs are children
Annexure P-4: Property documents (sale deed / title deed)
Annexure P-5: Mutation records showing fraudulent entry
Annexure P-6: Copy of forged will (if available)
Annexure P-7: Handwriting samples of deceased
Annexure P-8: FIR copy filed for forgery
Annexure P-9: Legal notice sent to defendant
Annexure P-10: Valuation certificate from approved valuer

court_fees_calculation.basis: Market value of property share claimed
court_fees_calculation.formula: As per Court Fees Act of respective state
court_fees_calculation.example: If property value is Rs. 50,00,000 and 3 heirs claim 1/3rd each → Each plaintiff's share = Rs. 16,66,667 → Court fees as per slab

procedural_steps.step1: Draft plaint with all facts and annexures
procedural_steps.step2: Calculate and pay court fees + stamp duty
procedural_steps.step3: File plaint in District Court registry
procedural_steps.step4: Court assigns case number and schedules first hearing
procedural_steps.step5: Simultaneously file application under Order 39 CPC for temporary injunction
procedural_steps.step6: Serve summons on defendant through court process
procedural_steps.step7: Defendant files written statement within 30-90 days
procedural_steps.step8: Court frames issues based on pleadings
procedural_steps.step14: If partition ordered, court appoints commissioner for physical division

time_estimate: Partition suits typically take 2-5 years depending on court workload and evidence complexity

legal_notes.hindu_succession_act: Section 8 gives equal rights to all Class I heirs (sons, daughters, widow, mother)
legal_notes.limitation: Article 65 - 12 years for possession-based suits; Article 59 - 3 years for declaratory suits from knowledge of fraud
legal_notes.injunction: Under Order 39 CPC, court can grant temporary injunction if: (1) Prima facie case, (2) Balance of convenience, (3) Irreparable injury
legal_notes.partition_right: Partition is a legal right. Court cannot refuse if property is capable of division.
legal_notes.third_party_rights: If defendant has sold to bona fide purchaser for value without notice, plaintiffs may be entitled to damages instead of property recovery
